Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Agricultural Trade and Adaptation to Environmental Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

One of the main economic effects of predicted changes in environmental factors will be largely driven by the agricultural sector, particularly in areas where most of the labor force works in agriculture and crops are already grown close to the limits of their thermal tolerance. This research investigates the extent to which increased trade between regions and across countries can help offset the adverse effects of environmental change. The project uses an estimated model of agricultural production and trade linking a large number of regional markets and countries. The model is used to run experiments comparing the effects of changes in environmental factors with existing high transport costs and policy barriers to those when these costs and barriers are reduced or removed.

This research expands on an existing model of agricultural trade by incorporating both an explicit model of land use choice based on recent advances in the international trade literature and a larger set of crops. The estimated model is used to simulate the baseline equilibrium with existing high trade costs and baseline productivity and then compare these results to those under counterfactual simulations with (i) lower trade costs; (ii) predicted productivity under environmental change; and (iii) both. The rich set of output of the model is then used to analyze the heterogeneity in effects on producers, consumers, and overall welfare in each simulation across a large number of regions. This research engages undergraduate research assistants in data collection, estimation and programming of the model, analysis of the model output. Furthermore, packaging of the model in a user-friendly format with complete documentation and open access will enable other researchers to use it for their experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research on how current and predicted environmental change is affecting the agricultural sector and the extent to which trade between regions and across countries can help offset potentially adverse effects. The findings from this research are documented in three papers:

1. Porteous, Obie. 2022. “Reverse Dutch Disease with Trade Costs: Prospects for Agriculture in Africa's Oil-Rich Economies.” Journal of International Economics 138: 103651.

Many countries are implementing environmental policies to reduce their carbon emissions. This is expected to lead to reduced global demand for oil. This paper focused on oil-rich countries and the effects that declining oil revenues will have on their agricultural production. I found that while past increases in oil revenues have led to a contraction and re-orientation of the agricultural sector in these countries away from exports and towards production of perishable goods for the domestic market, future decreases in oil revenues will reverse this trend, stimulating production of tradable agricultural goods. However, I also found that high trade costs (transport costs, policy barriers…) can prevent remote farmers from experiencing this beneficial effect. Policies that lower trade costs and increase agricultural productivity can help farmers in more remote areas benefit while offsetting the lost income from oil for the country as a whole.

2. Porteous, Obie, Hubert Kpoumie Mounmemi, Agnes Roche, Manon Le Bourgeois, and Christiane Laurette Mayumgo Kamga. "Adaptation to Climate Change by Smallholder Farmers: Evidence from Cameroon." Accepted by Atlantic Economic Journal.

Smallholder farmers in developing countries are particularly vulnerable to environmental change because their livelihoods depend on the weather. In this paper, we found that 76% of smallholder farmers we interviewed in Cameroon reported yield losses due to changes in their local climate. These effects were primarily due to changes in the timing of rainfall rather than in total rainfall or temperature, the variables typically used in studies of the effects of past climate change. The primary way in which farmers are adapting to these changes is by changing their cultivation practices like fertilizer and pesticide use. In contrast, existing models of future climate change typically assume that farmers will adapt by switching crops, changing the area of land they cultivate, or exiting agriculture. Our results will help improve future research on the effects of past and future climate change.

3. Porteous, Obie. "Agricultural Trade and Adaptation to Climate Change in Sub-Saharan Africa." Revisions requested by The Economic Journal. Submitted version (March 2024) available at: https://doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.4777962

Climate change is predicted to lead to large changes in agricultural yields, but these changes in yields will vary greatly across locations, and the ultimate effects they will have on human welfare will depend on the extent to which locations affected in different ways can trade with each other. For this paper, I assembled a model including agricultural production and consumption of 24 major crops in 271 regions in 43 African countries and trade of these crops both between these regions and with the rest of the world. Simulations with the estimated model showed a continent-wide 8% decrease in agricultural production, 11% increase in food prices, and welfare loss of 4.8% of baseline GDP due to climate change in 2071–2100 under the scenario with the most emissions (RCP8.5). To explore the potential role of trade in adaptation to climate change, I conducted a number of further experiments with the model. I found that the aggregate welfare loss was 15% smaller if the costs of trade (transport costs, policy barriers…) were lowered to match benchmark levels from elsewhere in the world and over 5 times larger if trade was restricted to current levels. These results suggest that countries should remain open to and facilitate trade in order to help their producers and consumers adjust to the changing climate.

The results of this project have direct policy implications for adaptation to environmental change, which could lead to improvements in social and economic conditions around the world while also informing related US government initiatives like Feed the Future. In addition, the documentation and dissemination of the estimated model used for the third paper described above will enable other researchers to use it to conduct their own policy experiments, potentially multiplying the impact of this project.

A total of 8 undergraduate research assistants worked on this project, including 5 female students and 4 students of color. These students were actively mentored and trained, and they gained experience with a variety of research skills, including survey design, data processing, economic modeling, and geographic data analysis. Two of these students accompanied me on a data collection trip to Cameroon and co-authored the resulting paper. This trip may become a model for other similar immersive research-based educational experiences in the future.
